title: “The Kidnapping I Can’t Escape”

A few years ago, I wrote a different novel, my first novel, about divorce, which was inspired in part by the divorce stories of several people I know, and I came to the conclusion that, actually, all divorces are exactly alike. I tell you this because Iâ€™ve now come to understand the same thing about trauma: Happy, well-adjusted people are all different. The traumatized are exactly alike. Iâ€™m about to tell you a story that is nothing like a violent kidnapping â€” almost laughably so â€” but what Iâ€™ve learned over the years is that trauma is trauma. Something terrible happens, beyond what is in our own personal capacity to cope with, and the details donâ€™t matter as much as the state weâ€™re thrown into. Our bodies and brains have not evolved to reliably differentiate a rape at knife point from a job loss that threatens us with financial ruin or from the dismantling of our world by our parentsâ€™ divorce. Itâ€™s wrong, but explain that to your poor, battered autonomic nervous system.
